body:
Thanks for adding this issue @imsodin. As you noted via the above forum post link, this issue bit me hard this week, so I would have benefited from some kind of mitigation.

Changing the defaults when the host is BSD would have been helpful, but honestly would not have helped me **that** much, because I probably would have simply turned it on when I set everything up.

Honestly, as a sysadmin, I would cast my vote for a UI warning along with some clear documentation around the risks and tradeoffs of enabling the feature. I think that would have saved me a couple days of hair-pulling.

To further clarify, I don't think the biggest issue is the performance impact itself. I think the biggest issue was the mystery of trying to figure out **what was causing** the performance impact. So a clear UI warning would have been incredibly helpful.

Thanks again for working on Syncthing. It's pretty incredible!

I agree, it took me several weeks of screwing around to finally figure out why anytime Syncthing was enabled my system would CRAWL and be literally unusable (which was tough to troubleshoot because the shell and webgui would actually time out before getting a response.) I was trying to install custom Syncthing jails with resource limits and all kinds of circular goose chasing, only to find out it was just an otherwise innocent looking setting...

So perhaps a one time notification similar to the "you should set up authentication" one, like "my dude, you're on a system with kqueue, use filesystem notifications with care and be aware that enabling it for large folders will use lots of system resources", perhaps with a link to some suitable doc article / faq...

Exactly. Just something to make the average user aware of the performance impact. For me, the filesystem watcher works flawlessly on my Windows and my prior Linux setup, but the FreeBSD version (that i only started using/learning a month ago) basically left me completely unaware.

Otherwise, its a pretty nice bit of code you've got here.
"Average user" and "BSD" in the same paragraph, wat?
Right. That is a fair point you have there.. Perhaps rookie, inexperienced or just plain dumbass (me) users might have been more precise - hard to say. Bahaha

i think, regardless of the user-model, (this) software should give relevant information to the user in order to not waste their time. So a notification should be fine. This would be in the bsd-spirit  :smile:
Is this a scalability issue? Could I fix the hang by adding another 128GB RAM to the box running Syncthing?
Its probably cheaper to move to linux, if you can.
I already tried and it didn't help
Tried what and what didn't help?
256GB RAM in the box, the issue described above still happens (~11M files)
Yes, on BSD watching large folders does not work, this is what issue talks about.

I can not confirm this general statement.
I have one TrueNAS server which totally works fine detecting changes on a summarized size of ~ 33TB (774 k files).
The other TrueNAS server I have is struggling as soon as I switch the on the watcher. So there must be something that allows it or cripples it.

Both systems are Supermicro ones.
The first system is my beafy main one (16 Cores, 2 Sockets, 128 GB RAM).
The second system is my backup system (4 Cores, 1 Socket propagated, 32 GB RAM).
Both have a X9 board and are using LSI/Broadcom JBOD controllers.
You have relatively few files, and by default the system limit on fd:s is relative to the amount of RAM.

So it isn't FreeBSD in general then, it is the amount of RAM - you say.
But what about 

> 256GB RAM in the box, the issue described above still happens (~11M files)
What about it?

> Yes, on BSD watching large folders does not work, this is what issue talks about.

To which the question arose, what is the limiting factor. Not memory, apparently.

Seems like this question should be asked on the BSD forums?
I don't think any of the syncthing maintainers can answer questions about BSD scalability concerns.

Yeah. The limit is max possible fd:s. This apparently scales with ram somehow, in at least some configurations. But really, the details are up to you as system administrator of your system to figure out. I don't think questioning us why 775k files hit the limit on 32 gigs when it doesn't on 128 gigs and how that rhymes with 11m files on 256 gigs is the thing. These are freebsd limits so apply freebsd knowledge.
